The Intel Xeon 6710E is a server/workstation processor with 64 cores, launched in June 2024, at an MSRP of $2749. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Sierra Forest-SP architecture with Socket 4710. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6710E CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6710E has 96 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.4 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.2 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6710E on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6710E, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 205 W, the Xeon 6710E is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 5600 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon 6710E uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6710E, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel is including the newer AVX2 standard, too, but not AVX-512.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6731E is a server/workstation processor with 96 cores, launched in June 2024, at an MSRP of $4121. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Sierra Forest-SP architecture with Socket 4710. Xeon 6731E has 96 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.2 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.1 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6731E on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6731E, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 250 W, the Xeon 6731E is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 5600 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6731E uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6731E, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel is including the newer AVX2 standard, too, but not AVX-512.
----------------------------

It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Sierra Forest-SP architecture with Socket 4710. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6740E CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6740E has 96 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.4 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.2 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6740E on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6740E, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 250 W, the Xeon 6740E is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon 6740E uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.

Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel is including the newer AVX2 standard, too, but not AVX-512.

The Intel Xeon 6746E is a server/workstation processor with 112 cores, launched in June 2024, at an MSRP of $5929. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Sierra Forest-SP architecture with Socket 4710. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6746E CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6746E has 96 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 2.7 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6746E on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6746E, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 250 W, the Xeon 6746E is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 5600 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon 6746E uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6746E, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel is including the newer AVX2 standard, too, but not AVX-512.

It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Sierra Forest-SP architecture with Socket 4710. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6756E CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6756E has 96 MB of L3 cache and operates at 1800 MHz by default, but can boost up to 2.6 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6756E on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6756E, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 225 W, the Xeon 6756E is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6756E uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6756E, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel is including the newer AVX2 standard, too, but not AVX-512.

The Intel Xeon 6766E is a server/workstation processor with 144 cores, launched in June 2024, at an MSRP of $10257. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Sierra Forest-SP architecture with Socket 4710. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6766E CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6766E has 108 MB of L3 cache and operates at 1900 MHz by default, but can boost up to 2.7 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6766E on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6766E, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 250 W, the Xeon 6766E is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon 6766E uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6766E, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel is including the newer AVX2 standard, too, but not AVX-512.

The Intel Xeon 6780E is a server/workstation processor with 144 cores, launched in June 2024, at an MSRP of $11350. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Sierra Forest-SP architecture with Socket 4710. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6780E CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6780E has 108 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.2 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6780E on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6780E, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 330 W, the Xeon 6780E is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon 6780E uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6780E, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel is including the newer AVX2 standard, too, but not AVX-512.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6952P is a server/workstation processor with 96 cores, launched in September 2024. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-AP architecture with Socket 7529. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 192 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6952P CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6952P has 480 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6952P on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6952P, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 400 W, the Xeon 6952P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a twelve-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6952P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6952P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6960P is a server/workstation processor with 72 cores, launched in September 2024. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-AP architecture with Socket 7529. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 144 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6960P CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6960P has 432 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.7 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6960P on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6960P, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 500 W, the Xeon 6960P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a twelve-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon 6960P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6960P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

The Intel Xeon 6980P is a server/workstation processor with 128 cores, launched in September 2024. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-AP architecture with Socket 7529. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 256 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6980P CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6980P has 504 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6980P on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6980P, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 500 W, the Xeon 6980P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a twelve-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon 6980P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6980P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 5411N is a server/workstation processor with 28 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $1388. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 56 threads. Xeon Gold 5411N has 45 MB of L3 cache and operates at 1900 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Gold 5411N on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 5411N, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 165 W, the Xeon Gold 5411N is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Gold 5411N uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 5411N, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------

The Intel Xeon Gold 5420+ is a server/workstation processor with 28 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $1848. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 56 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 5420+ CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 5420+ has 52.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 4.1 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Gold 5420+ on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 5420+, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 205 W, the Xeon Gold 5420+ is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon Gold 5420+ uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 5420+, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 5423N is a server/workstation processor with 20 cores, launched in January 2023. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 40 threads. Xeon Gold 5423N has 37.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Gold 5423N on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 5423N, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 145 W, the Xeon Gold 5423N consumes a lot of power, so good cooling is definitely needed. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4000 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Gold 5423N uses a PCI-Express Gen 4 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 5423N, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 5433N is a server/workstation processor with 20 cores, launched in January 2023. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 5512U is a server/workstation processor with 28 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $1230. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 56 threads. Xeon Gold 5512U has 52.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.7 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Gold 5512U on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 5512U, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 185 W, the Xeon Gold 5512U is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Gold 5512U uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 5512U, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 5520+ is a server/workstation processor with 28 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $1640. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 56 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 5520+ CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 5520+ has 52.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.2 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Gold 5520+ on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 5520+, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 205 W, the Xeon Gold 5520+ is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon Gold 5520+ uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 5520+, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 6414U is a server/workstation processor with 32 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $2296. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 64 threads. Xeon Gold 6414U has 60 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.4 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Gold 6414U on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 6414U, which limits its overclocking potential.

For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Gold 6414U uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 6414U, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

To further increase overall system performance, up to four Xeon Gold 6416H CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 6526Y, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 6530 is a server/workstation processor with 32 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $2128. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 64 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 6530 CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 6530 has 160 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Gold 6530 on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 6530, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 270 W, the Xeon Gold 6530 is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Gold 6530 uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 6530, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 6538N is a server/workstation processor with 32 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $3351. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 64 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 6538N CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 6538N has 60 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4.1 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Gold 6538N on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 6538N, which limits its overclocking capabilities.

For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Gold 6538N uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.

Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

The Intel Xeon Gold 6544Y is a server/workstation processor with 16 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $3622. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 32 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 6544Y CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 6544Y has 45 MB of L3 cache and operates at 3.6 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4.1 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Gold 6544Y on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 6544Y, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 270 W, the Xeon Gold 6544Y is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 5200 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Gold 6544Y uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.

Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

The Intel Xeon Silver 4416+ is a server/workstation processor with 20 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $1186. It is part of the Xeon Silver lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 40 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Silver 4416+ CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Silver 4416+ has 37.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Silver 4416+ on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Silver 4416+, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 165 W, the Xeon Silver 4416+ is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4000 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Silver 4416+ uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Silver 4416+, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

The Intel Xeon Platinum 8444H is a server/workstation processor with 16 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $4234. It is part of the Xeon Platinum lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 32 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to eight Xeon Platinum 8444H CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Platinum 8444H has 45 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.9 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Platinum 8444H on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Platinum 8444H, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 270 W, the Xeon Platinum 8444H is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon Platinum 8444H uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Platinum 8444H, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

Xeon Platinum 8462Y+ has 60 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.8 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4.1 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Platinum 8462Y+ on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Platinum 8462Y+, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 300 W, the Xeon Platinum 8462Y+ is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Platinum 8462Y+ uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Platinum 8462Y+, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Platinum 8468 is a server/workstation processor with 48 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $7214. It is part of the Xeon Platinum lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 96 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Platinum 8468 CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Platinum 8468 has 105 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.8 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Platinum 8468 on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Platinum 8468, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 350 W, the Xeon Platinum 8468 is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon Platinum 8468 uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Platinum 8468, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Platinum 8468H is a server/workstation processor with 48 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $13923. To further increase overall system performance, up to eight Xeon Platinum 8468H CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. The Intel Xeon Platinum 8468V is a server/workstation processor with 48 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $7121. It is part of the Xeon Platinum lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 96 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Platinum 8468V CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Platinum 8468V has 97.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.4 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.8 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Platinum 8468V on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Platinum 8468V, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 330 W, the Xeon Platinum 8468V is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon Platinum 8468V uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Platinum 8468V, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Platinum 8470 is a server/workstation processor with 52 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $9359. It is part of the Xeon Platinum lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 104 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Platinum 8470 CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Platinum 8470 has 105 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.8 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Platinum 8470 on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Platinum 8470, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 350 W, the Xeon Platinum 8470 is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Platinum 8470 uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Platinum 8470, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

It is part of the Xeon Platinum lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 104 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Platinum 8470N CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Platinum 8470N has 97.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 1700 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.6 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Platinum 8470N on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Platinum 8470N, which limits its overclocking potential.

The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon Platinum 8470N uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Platinum 8470N, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

The Intel Xeon Platinum 8558 is a server/workstation processor with 48 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $4650. It is part of the Xeon Platinum lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 96 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Platinum 8558 CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Platinum 8558 has 260 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Platinum 8558 on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Platinum 8558, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 330 W, the Xeon Platinum 8558 is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 5200 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Platinum 8558 uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Platinum 8558, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Platinum 8581V is a server/workstation processor with 64 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $7568. It is part of the Xeon Platinum lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 128 threads. Xeon Platinum 8581V has 300 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Platinum 8581V on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Platinum 8581V, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 270 W, the Xeon Platinum 8581V is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon Platinum 8581V uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Platinum 8581V, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Platinum 8592+ is a server/workstation processor with 64 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $11600. It is part of the Xeon Platinum lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 128 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Platinum 8592+ CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Platinum 8592+ has 320 MB of L3 cache and operates at 1900 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Platinum 8592+ on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Platinum 8592+, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 350 W, the Xeon Platinum 8592+ is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 5600 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon Platinum 8592+ uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Platinum 8592+, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Platinum 8592V is a server/workstation processor with 64 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $10995. It is part of the Xeon Platinum lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 128 threads. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Platinum 8593Q is a server/workstation processor with 64 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $12400. It is part of the Xeon Platinum lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 128 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Platinum 8593Q CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Platinum 8593Q has 320 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.2 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Platinum 8593Q on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Platinum 8593Q, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 385 W, the Xeon Platinum 8593Q is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 5600 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Platinum 8593Q uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Platinum 8593Q, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Max 9460 is a server/workstation processor with 40 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $8750. It is part of the Xeon Max lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 80 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Max 9460 CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Max 9460 has 97.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.2 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.5 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Max 9460 on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Max 9460, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 350 W, the Xeon Max 9460 is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon Max 9460 uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Max 9460, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Max 9462 is a server/workstation processor with 32 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $7995. It is part of the Xeon Max lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 64 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Max 9462 CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Max 9462 has 75 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.7 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.5 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Max 9462 on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Max 9462, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 350 W, the Xeon Max 9462 is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon Max 9462 uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Max 9462, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

The Intel Xeon Max 9468 is a server/workstation processor with 48 cores, launched in January 2023, at an MSRP of $9900. It is part of the Xeon Max lineup, using the Sapphire Rapids architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 96 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Max 9468 CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. AMD CPU Long Descriptions (scraped from TechPowerUp)
====================================================
The Intel Xeon Gold 5512U is a server/workstation processor with 28 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $1230. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 56 threads. Xeon Gold 5512U has 52.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.7 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Gold 5512U on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 5512U, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 185 W, the Xeon Gold 5512U is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon Gold 5512U uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 5512U, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 5515+ is a server/workstation processor with 8 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $1099. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 16 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 5515+ CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 5515+ has 22.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 3.2 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4.1 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Gold 5515+ on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 5515+, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 165 W, the Xeon Gold 5515+ is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon Gold 5515+ uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 5515+, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 5520+ is a server/workstation processor with 28 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $1640. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 56 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 5520+ CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 5520+ has 52.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.2 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Gold 5520+ on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 5520+, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 205 W, the Xeon Gold 5520+ is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon Gold 5520+ uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 5520+, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 6526Y is a server/workstation processor with 16 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $1517. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 32 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 6526Y CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 6526Y has 37.5 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.8 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Gold 6526Y on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 6526Y, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 195 W, the Xeon Gold 6526Y is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 5200 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon Gold 6526Y uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 6526Y, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 64 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 6530 CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 6530 has 160 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon Gold 6530 on a 10 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 6530, which limits its overclocking capabilities.

Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 6548Y+ is a server/workstation processor with 32 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $3726. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 64 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 6548Y+ CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 6548Y+ has 60 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.5 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4.1 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Gold 6548Y+ on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 6548Y+, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 250 W, the Xeon Gold 6548Y+ is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 5200 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon Gold 6548Y+ uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon Gold 6548Y+, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon Gold 6554S is a server/workstation processor with 36 cores, launched in December 2023, at an MSRP of $3157. It is part of the Xeon Gold lineup, using the Emerald Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4677. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 72 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon Gold 6554S CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon Gold 6554S has 180 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.2 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon Gold 6554S on a 10 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon Gold 6554S, which limits its overclocking potential.

Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

The Intel Xeon 6503P-B is a server/workstation processor with 12 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $934. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-D architecture with BGA 4368. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 24 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6503P-B CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6503P-B has 48 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.5 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6503P-B on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6503P-B, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 110 W, the Xeon 6503P-B consumes a lot of power, so good cooling is definitely needed. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a quad-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon 6503P-B uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.

Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. With a TDP of 150 W, the Xeon 6507P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon 6507P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6507P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6511P is a server/workstation processor with 16 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $815. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4710. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 32 threads. Xeon 6511P has 72 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.3 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4.2 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6511P on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6511P, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 150 W, the Xeon 6511P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon 6511P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6511P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6513P-B is a server/workstation processor with 20 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $1399. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-D architecture with BGA 4368. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 40 threads. Xeon 6513P-B has 80 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.3 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6513P-B on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6513P-B, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 130 W, the Xeon 6513P-B consumes a lot of power, so good cooling is definitely needed. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a quad-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 5600 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon 6513P-B uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6513P-B, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6515P is a server/workstation processor with 16 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $740. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4710. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 32 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6515P CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6515P has 72 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.3 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.8 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6515P on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6515P, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 150 W, the Xeon 6515P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6515P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6515P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6516P-B is a server/workstation processor with 20 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $1544. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-D architecture with BGA 4368. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 40 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6516P-B CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6516P-B has 80 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.3 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.5 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6516P-B on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6516P-B, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 145 W, the Xeon 6516P-B consumes a lot of power, so good cooling is definitely needed. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a quad-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 4800 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6516P-B uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6516P-B, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

The Intel Xeon 6520P is a server/workstation processor with 24 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $1295. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4710. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 48 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6520P CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6520P has 144 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.4 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6520P on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6520P, which limits its overclocking potential.

For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon 6714P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6714P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications.
