Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6716P-B, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6724P is a server/workstation processor with 16 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $3622. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4710. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 32 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to eight Xeon 6724P CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6724P has 72 MB of L3 cache and operates at 3.6 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4.3 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6724P on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6724P, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 210 W, the Xeon 6724P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6724P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6724P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6726P-B is a server/workstation processor with 42 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $3795. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-D architecture with BGA 4368. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 84 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6726P-B CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6726P-B has 168 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.3 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.5 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6726P-B on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6726P-B, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 235 W, the Xeon 6726P-B is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a quad-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon 6726P-B uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6726P-B, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------

The Intel Xeon 6788P is a server/workstation processor with 86 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $19000. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4710. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 172 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to eight Xeon 6788P CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6788P has 336 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.8 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6788P on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6788P, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 350 W, the Xeon 6788P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6788P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6788P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6944P is a server/workstation processor with 72 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $6850. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-AP architecture with Socket 7529. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 144 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6944P CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6944P has 432 MB of L3 cache and operates at 1800 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6944P on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6944P, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 350 W, the Xeon 6944P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a twelve-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6944P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6944P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6952P is a server/workstation processor with 96 cores, launched in September 2024, at an MSRP of $9115. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-AP architecture with Socket 7529. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 192 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6952P CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6952P has 480 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6952P on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6952P, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 400 W, the Xeon 6952P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a twelve-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6952P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6952P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6960P is a server/workstation processor with 72 cores, launched in September 2024, at an MSRP of $9625. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-AP architecture with Socket 7529. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 144 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6960P CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6960P has 432 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.7 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6960P on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6960P, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 500 W, the Xeon 6960P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a twelve-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon 6960P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6960P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6972P is a server/workstation processor with 96 cores, launched in September 2024, at an MSRP of $10220. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-AP architecture with Socket 7529. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 192 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6972P CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6972P has 480 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.4 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6972P on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6972P, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 500 W, the Xeon 6972P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a twelve-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the computer, Xeon 6972P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6972P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6979P is a server/workstation processor with 120 cores, launched in September 2024, at an MSRP of $11025. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-AP architecture with Socket 7529. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 240 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6979P CPUs can link up in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6979P has 504 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is building the Xeon 6979P on a 5 nm production process, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6979P, which limits its overclocking capabilities.
With a TDP of 500 W, the Xeon 6979P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a twelve-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6979P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6979P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) will run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
----------------------------
The Intel Xeon 6980P is a server/workstation processor with 128 cores, launched in September 2024, at an MSRP of $12460. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-AP architecture with Socket 7529. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 256 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6980P CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6980P has 504 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2000 MHz by default, but can boost up to 3.9 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6980P on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6980P, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 500 W, the Xeon 6980P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with a twelve-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon 6980P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6980P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
